instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

LVDS area damage (from end user forcing on a 2011 panel)
Blown BKL fuse.
Green light, no fan spin.
Charges battery, no power on with battery.
CPU cold,

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.56
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.56
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.416
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.279
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0v

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.386v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.386v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> =3.3v


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> =0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VSUS_EN</SIGNAL> =0

<CHIP>U7940</CHIP>
PIN5 VCC 3.32v
PIN6 0v (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>)
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> =3.3v

<RESISTOR>R1923</RESISTOR> ( for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>) 0v

Lost on this one, would you have any suggestions please ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message: Did you check for any shorts on the s3 lines onwards ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
Is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.01V or 0V? You specify it twice in your post

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> high? <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
Forcing a wrong connector can only really affect power on if <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> gets shorted. But if that happened the backlight fuse could never have blown as it needs to boot to do that.
After that it could be anything as it is probably some random component knocked off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
Thanks for your replies, this apparently was at another shop before (joy).

Apologies <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 5.01v, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0v (copy paste went wrong)

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4v


Checking for shorts on S3/S0 rails
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>  diode mode 0.395 drop to ground.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 0.330 diode mode
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.386 diode mode

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.375 diode mode
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0.283 diode mode



<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is 0.54v - significant ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is that voltage drop in diode mode or trace voltage?
Resistance to ground in Ohms?

Honestly no idea what this could be, check the board for any ugliness or missing parts. Take your time with this as they're sometimes hard to find

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message:
Thank you for the reply.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> has trace voltage of 0.54v (unit powered on voltage mode multimeter)
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> measured at <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> pin 4 is 7Kohm diode mode voltage drop to ground is 0.356v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message: Any chance you have a oscilloscope to see if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message: yes i do (not used very often).  No pulsing at all on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light no power missing SUS
threads.message: Could be anything, I bet it  is some knocked off component as there is more idiot damage. Check PPVRTC too
